facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 195 of 1962 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 195 of 1962.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated August 24, 1961 of Patna High Court in M.J.C. No. 126 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated 1961, August 24 of the Patna High Court in M. J. C. No. 126 of 1961.

facts.text: Judgment of Supreme Court delivered on July 31, 1962 by WANCHOO, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. July 31. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO, J.-This is an appeal

facts.text: New route Gopalganj-Pahlezghat advertised by North Bihar Regional Transport Authority in July 1957 with two vacancies for permanent stage carriage permits.

anchor.surface_text: Brief facts necessary for present purposes are these. It appears that a new route Gopalganj-Pahlezghat was advertised by the North Bihar Regional Transport Authority in July 1957 and applications were invited for permanent stage carriage permits and the advertisement stated that there were two vacancies on the route.

facts.text: Number of persons applied for the two permits on the new route.

anchor.surface_text: A number of persons applied for the two permits and in January 1958, the Regional Transport Authority granted permits to the appellant and another person.

facts.text: In January 1958, Regional Transport Authority granted permits to appellant and another person.

anchor.surface_text: A number of persons applied for the two permits and in January 1958, the Regional Transport Authority granted permits to the appellant and another person.

facts.text: Order of Regional Transport Authority appealed to Appellate Authority, which failed.

anchor.surface_text: This order was taken in appeal to the Appellate Authority, which however failed.

facts.text: Sudhakar Sharma moved Patna High Court under Article 226 of Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter Sudhakar Sharma who is one of the respondents, before us, moved the High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution

facts.text: In April 1960, Patna High Court quashed order of Appellate Authority based on Ram Gopal v. Anant Prasad.

anchor.surface_text: and in April 1960 the High Court quashed the order of the Appellate Authority on the basis of the judgment of this Court in Ram Gopal v. Anant Prasad.

facts.text: Case remanded to Appellate Authority for rehearing.

anchor.surface_text: The case then went back to the Appellate Authority for rehearing.

facts.text: Appellate Authority modified Regional Transport Authority order: cancelled appellant's permit, granted to Sudhakar Sharma; other permit unchanged.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Authority thereupon modified the order of the Regional Transport Authority and the permit granted to the appellant was cancelled and in his place a permit was granted to Sudhakar Sharma, the permit granted to the other person was number interfered with.

facts.text: Appellant applied to State Government under s.64A of Motor Vehicles Act as amended by Bihar Act 27 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, the appellant made an application to the State Government under s. 64-A of the Motor Vehicles Act, No.4 of 1939, hereinafter referred to as the Act  as amended by the Bihar Amendment

facts.text: Minister for Transport upheld Appellate Authority order but ordered additional permit to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The application was heard by the Minister for Transport and he upheld the order of the appellate Authority. At the same times however, he took the view that with the introduction of bus-service in North Bihar, people are becoming more and more bus-minded as they have been getting cheap and quick means of transport and therefore an additional service companyld be allowed on this route, and that would add to the facilities provided to the public without impairing in any way the effectively of the existing service. Therefore, while upholding the order of the Appellate Authority cancelling the permit of the appellant and granting a permit instead to Sudhakar Sharma, he felt that the ends of justice would be met if an additional permit was granted to the appellant, who had proved to be a desirable operator. He therefore ordered that an additional service be allowed to the appellant for the said route.

facts.text: Ram Kailash Pandey filed writ petition in High Court challenging Minister's order granting additional permit to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon Ram Kailash Pandey who had also made an application under s. 64-A and whose -application had been dismissed filed a write petition before the High Court challenging the order of the Minister for Transport.

facts.text: High Court held State Government had no power under s.64A to increase permits from two to three, set aside grant of third permit to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: When the petition came to be heard before the High Court it was companytended that the State Government had numberpower when dealing with an application under s. 64-A, to increase the number of permits to be granted from two which was the limit fixed by the Regional Transport Authority, to three, and therefore, its order granting the third permit to the appellant was without jurisdiction. This companytention was accepted by the High Court, and it set aside that part of the order by which a third permit was granted to the appellant.

facts.text: High Court refused to interfere with permits granted to other two persons.

anchor.surface_text: But the High Court refused to interfere with the rest of the order granting permits to the two other persons.

facts.text: Appellant applied for certificate to appeal to Supreme Court, refused; then special leave granted.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, the appellant applied for a certificate to appeal to this Court, which was refused. He then moved this Court for special leave, which was granted and that is how the matter has companye up before us.

facts.text: Regional Transport Authority advertised two vacancies for new route, implying limit fixed under s.47(3).

anchor.surface_text: But the High Court has held that the number can be deemed to have been fixed in view of the advertisement issued by the Regional Transport Authority calling for applications for two vacancies.

facts.text: Route Gopalganj-Pahlezghat was a new route opened for the first time.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that a new route Gopalganj-Pahlezghat was advertised by the North Bihar Regional Transport Authority in July 1957

facts.text: Sudhakar Sharma is respondent No.1.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter Sudhakar Sharma who is one of the respondents, before us,

facts.text: Ram Kailash Pandey made application under s.64A which was dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon Ram Kailash Pandey who had also made an application under s. 64-A and whose -application had been dismissed

facts.text: Parties to writ petition: appellant, two permit holders, State of Bihar, Appellate Authority, Regional Transport Authority.

anchor.surface_text: To this petition the appellant as well as the two persons to whom permits were granted and the State of Bihar, the Appellate Authority as well as the Regional Transport Authority were made parties.

facts.text: Supreme Court infers that for new route, advertisement of two vacancies means RTA fixed limit of two under s.47(3).

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that in this case a new route was being advertised for the first time and the advertisement said that there were two vacancies for which applications were invited, In the case of a new route it is clear that the Regional Transport Authority must have companye to some companyclusion as to the number of stage carriages which were to be permitted to operate on that route and the advertisement would only be issued on behalf of the Regional Transport Authority calling for applications for the number so fixed.

facts.text: No resolution on record explicitly fixing limit to two stage carriages.

anchor.surface_text: it is true that there is numberhing on the record to prove that there was any resolution as such by the Regional Transport Authority in this case limiting the number of stage carriages on this route to two.

issues.text: The main question for decision in this appeal is whether the State Government acting under s. 64-A of the Bihar Amendment Act had the power to increase the number of permits for which application had been invited by the Regional Transport Authority.

anchor.surface_text: The main question for decision in this appeal is whether the State Government acting under s. 64-A of the Bihar Amendment Act had the power to increase the number of permits for which application had been invited by the Regional Transport Authority.

issues.text: whether the Regional Transport Authority had fixed a limit on the number of stage carriage permits under s. 47(3)

anchor.surface_text: It is further contended on behalf of the appellant that there were no limits fixed by the Regional Transport Authority and therefore it was open to the State Government to increase the number of permits from two to three.

issues.text: whether the number of permits can be deemed to have been fixed under s. 47(3) in view of the advertisement issued by the Regional Transport Authority calling for applications for two vacancies on a new route

anchor.surface_text: But the High Court has held that the number can be deemed to have been fixed in view of the advertisement issued by the Regional Transport Authority calling for applications for two vacancies.

issues.text: whether respondent No. 1 who filed the writ petition in the High Court had locus standi
whether s. 64-A as inserted by Central Act No. 100 of 1956 has by necessary implication repealed s. 64-A as inserted by the Bihar Amendment Act

anchor.surface_text: A question may very well arise whether s. 64-A as inserted by Central Act No. 100 of 1956 has by necessary implication repealed s. 64-A as inserted by the Bihar Amendment Act.

arguments.claim: State Government had no power under s.64A to increase the number of permits from two (limit fixed by RTA) to three

anchor.surface_text: When the petition came to be heard before the High Court it was contended that the State Government had no power when dealing with an application under s. 64-A, to increase the number of permits to be granted from two which was the limit fixed by the Regional Transport Authority, to three, and therefore, its order granting the third permit to the appellant was without jurisdiction.

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed after analyzing scheme of Chapter IV; s.64A confined to matters under s.48/s.64 within s.47(3) limit

arguments.claim: State Government has the same power under s.64A as the Regional Transport Authority, which includes power to increase number of permits

anchor.surface_text: It is contended on behalf of the appellant that the State Government has the same power under s. 64-A as the Regional Transport Authority has, as held by this Court in RAM GOPALS CASE, and it was therefore open to the State Government to increase the number of permits as the Regional Transport Authority would always have the power to increase the number of permits whenever it thought necessary to do so.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: r s. 64-A of the Bihar Amendment Act had the power to increase the number of permits for which application had been invited by the Regional Transport

arguments.court_reasoning: s.64A revision confined to selection among applicants within s.47(3) limit; RTA power to revise limit under s.47(3) separate from s.48 grant power; cites Ram Gopal and Arunachalam Pillai

arguments.claim: No limits fixed by Regional Transport Authority under s.47(3) as no resolution on record

anchor.surface_text: It is further contended on behalf of the appellant that there were no limits fixed by the Regional Transport Authority and therefore it was open to the State Government to increase the number of permits from two to three.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: may be revised at any time by the Regional Transport Authority if it properly companyes to the companyclusion that revision is necessary in view of th

arguments.court_reasoning: For new route advertised first time specifying two vacancies, infer RTA fixed limit of two under s.47(3)

arguments.claim: Respondent No.1 had no locus standi to file writ petition in High Court
arguments.court_reasoning: Resp No.1 contended he should have been granted permit instead of appellant

arguments.claim: Under scheme of Chapter IV, RTA grant under s.48 subject to limit fixed under s.47(3)

anchor.surface_text: It would be clear therefore that when the Regional Transport Authority proceeds in the manner provided in S. 57 to consider an application for a stage carriage permit and eventually decides either to grant it or not to grant it under s. 48 its order has to be subject to the provisions of s. 47, including s. 47 3

arguments.claim: Appellate authority under s.64 and revisional authority under s.64A confined to matters RTA could consider under s.48, i.e., choosing between applicants within s.47(3) limit

anchor.surface_text: the power of the revisional authority is confined only to considering matters which the Regional Transport Authority and the Appellate Authority could have considered under s. 48 and s. 64.

arguments.claim: RTA power to revise s.47(3) limit is separate from power to grant permits under s.48

anchor.surface_text: The power to revise the limits under s. 47 3 in the Regional Transport Authority must not be confused with the powers which it has when it is dealing with the grant or refusal of permits under s. 48.

arguments.claim: For new route opened first time, advertisement specifying two vacancies infers RTA fixed limit of two under s.47(3)

anchor.surface_text: But the High Court has held that the number can be deemed to have been fixed in view of the advertisement issued by the Regional Transport Authority calling for applications for two vacancies. ... In the case of a new route it is clear that the Regional Transport Authority must have come to some conclusion as to the number of stage carriages which were to be permitted to operate on that route

arguments.claim: s.64A as per Ram Gopal and Arunachalam Pillai does not allow orders beyond subordinate authority's power

anchor.surface_text: This was the view taken by this Court in Ram Gopals case and the same view has been reiterated in A.S.T.Arunachalam Pillai v. Messrs. Southern Roadways Private Limited, where it was pointed out that though the words as it deems fit in s. 64-A are wide in expression, they do not mean that the State Government can pass any order

arguments.claim: Proviso to s.57(3) shows grants under s.48/s.57 within s.47(3) limit

anchor.surface_text: We may in this connection refer to the proviso to s. 57 3 introduced in 1956 which lays down that where limits have been fixed under s. 47 3 the Regional Transport Authority may summarily refuse applications for permit if the result of granting permits on such application would be to increase the number

holdings.text: The State Government acting under s. 64-A of the Bihar Amendment Act had no power to increase the number of permits from two to three where the Regional Transport Authority had fixed the limit at two under s. 47(3).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of Chapter IV confines s.48 grants, s.64 appeals, s.64A revisions to selection among applicants within s.47(3) limit; revision of limit under s.47(3) is separate power; follows Ram Gopal and Arunachalam Pillai.

holdings.text: When the Regional Transport Authority proceeds to grant permits under s.48 read with s.57, it must act subject to the limit fixed under s.47(3).

anchor.surface_text: Section 47 3  which is important gives power to the Regional Transport Authority to limit the number of stage carriages generally or of any specified type for which stage carriage permits may be granted in the region or in and specified area or on any specified route within the region, having regard to matter mentioned in sub s. 1 Section 48 then provides that subject to the provisions of s. 47,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of s.48 'subject to s.47'; s.47(3) empowers general limit based on s.47(1) criteria, distinct from individual grant stage; proviso s.57(3) confirms.

holdings.text: Appellate authority under s.64 and revisional authority under s.64A, when dealing with appeals/revisions from s.48 orders, are confined to choosing between applicants within the s.47(3) limit and cannot exceed it.

anchor.surface_text: Section 64 provides for an appeal from certain orders passed by the Regional Transport Authority within prescribed time and in the prescribed manner to the pres- cribed authority. Then comes s. 64-A, as inserted by the Bihar Amendment Act providing for revision by the State Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.64 does not appeal s.47(3) orders; revisional power limited to subordinate powers per precedents; wide words 'as it thinks fit' do not permit exceeding jurisdiction.

holdings.text: Power to revise s.47(3) limit is separate from power to grant/refuse individual permits under s.48; revision/appeal from grant cannot revise the limit.

anchor.surface_text: The power to revise the limits under s. 47 3 in the Regional Transport Authority must not be confused with the powers which it has when it is dealing with the grant or refusal of permits under s. 48.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes general limit-fixing stage from applicant selection stage; s.48 always subject to s.47.

holdings.text: In case of a new route advertised for the first time specifying two vacancies, it is reasonable to infer that the Regional Transport Authority had fixed the limit of two under s.47(3).

anchor.surface_text: it is true that there is nothing on the record to prove that there was any resolution as such by the Regional Transport Authority in this case limiting the number of stage carriages on this route to two. But the High Court has held that the number can be deemed to have been fixed in view of the advertisement issued by the Regional Transport Authority calling for applications for two vacancies.

holdings.reasoning_summary: For new route, RTA must conclude on number before advertising; specifying vacancies implies limit fixed; distinguishes from existing routes with vacancies due to expiries.

holdings.text: Respondent No.1 had locus standi to file the writ petition as he contended he should have been granted the permit instead of the appellant.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Directly aggrieved by permit grant to another over himself.

holdings.text: The view of the Allahabad High Court in Mohammad Luqman Sharif v. State Transport Authority is correct; appellate authority cannot refix number limited under equivalent of s.47(3).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Consistent with Chapter IV scheme and limitations on appellate/revisional powers.

anchor.surface_text: Ram Gopal v. Anant Prasad. 1  The case then went back to the Appellate Authority for rehearing. The Appellate Authority thereupon modified the order of the Regional Transport Authority and the permit granted to the appellant was cancelled and in his place a permit was granted to Sudhakar Sharma, the permit granted to the other person was number interfered with.

Southern Roadways  Private  Limited,  2 where it was pointed out that though the words as it deems fit in a. 64-A are wide in expression, they do number mean that the State Government can pass any order when exercising revisional authority which the authority whose orders the Government is revising has number authority to pass.

precedents.citation: A.S.T.Arunachalam Pillai v. Messrs. Southern Roadways Private Limited, 2

anchor.surface_text: A.S.T.Arunachalam Pillai v. Messrs. Southern Roadways  Private  Limited,  2 where it was pointed out that though the words as it deems fit in a. 64-A are wide in expression, they do number mean that the State Government can pass any order when exercising revisional authority which the authority whose orders the Government is revising has number authority to pass. The argument on behalf of the appellant is that the Regional Transport Authority undoubtedly has the, power to revise a general order passed under s. 47  3

precedents.case_name: A.S.T. Arunachalam Pillai v. Messrs. Southern Roadways Private Limited
precedents.cited_proposition: words 'as it deems fit' in s. 64-A do not allow State Government to pass orders beyond authority of subordinate body

precedents.citation: The Automobile Transport Rajasthan v. Shri Nahtu Ram Mirdha 1

anchor.surface_text: The Rajasthan High Court in The Automobile Transport  Rajasthan  v. Shri Nahtu Ram Mirdha  1  has taken one view and the Allahabad High Court in Mohammad Luqman Sharif v. State Transport Authority  2  has taken the companytrary view. The Rajasthan High Court held, dealing with s. 48  a  of the Act  as it was before the amendment of 1956  which is similar to s. 47  3  after the amendment, that under s. 48  a  as it stood before the amendment, limiting of the number of stage carriages On any specific route did number make the order of the Regional Transport Authority a final decision binding on

precedents.case_name: Automobile Transport Rajasthan v. Shri Nahtu Ram Mirdha
precedents.cited_proposition: order limiting number of stage carriages under s. 48A (pre-1956) not binding on appellate authority

precedents.citation: Mohammad Luqman Sharif v. State Transport Authority 2

anchor.surface_text: the Allahabad High Court in Mohammad Luqman Sharif v. State Transport Authority  2  has taken the companytrary view. The Rajasthan High Court held... The, Allahabad High Court on the other hand held that, when an order limiting the number of stage carriages had been passed under s. 48  a  as it was before the amendment of 1956, there companyld be numberappeal against that order under s. 64 and therefore the Appellate Authority on an appeal under s. 64 companyld riot refix the number of stage carriages in respect of that route.

precedents.case_name: Mohammad Luqman Sharif v. State Transport Authority
precedents.cited_proposition: no appeal under s. 64 against order limiting number under s. 48A (pre-1956), appellate cannot refix number

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the High Court was right on the facts of this case in holding that the State Government bad numberpower to increase the number of permits which bad been fixed at two by the Regional Transport Authority under s. 47  3  to three on the application of an aggrieved person under s. 64-A arising from a proceeding before the Regional Transport Authority under a. 48 and the Appellate Authority under s. 61.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court order upheld; State Government had no power under s. 64-A to grant additional permit increasing number beyond limit fixed under s. 47(3); appellant's contention rejected

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the High Court was right on the facts of this case in holding that the State Government bad numberpower to increase the number of permits which bad been fixed at two by the Regional Transport Authority under s. 47  3  to three on the application of an aggrieved person under s. 64-A arising from a proceeding before the Regional Transport Authority under a. 48 and the Appellate Authority under s. 61.

anchor.surface_text: Section 64 provides for an appeal from certain orders passed by the Regional Transport Authority within prescribed time and in the prescribed manner to the pres- cribed authority. Then comes s. 64-A, as inserted by the Bihar Amendment Act providing for revision by the State Government.

We are therefore of opinion that the High Court was right on the facts of this case in holding that the State Government bad numberpower to increase the number of permits which bad been fixed at two by the Regional Transport Authority under s. 47  3  to three on the application of an aggrieved person under s. 64-A arising from a proceeding before the Regional Transport Authority under a. 48 and the Appellate Authority under s. 61.

We are therefore of opinion that the High Court was right on the facts of this case in holding that the State Government bad numberpower to increase the number of permits which bad been fixed at two by the Regional Transport Authority under s. 47  3  to three on the application of an aggrieved person under s. 64-A arising from a proceeding before the Regional Transport Authority under a. 48 and the Appellate Authority under s. 61.

it is true that there is nothing on the record to prove that there was any resolution as such by the Regional Transport Authority in this case limiting the number of stage carriages on this route to two. But the High Court has held that the number can be deemed to have been fixed in view of the advertisement issued by the Regional Transport Authority calling for applications for two vacancies.

We are therefore of opinion that the High Court was right on the facts of this case in holding that the State Government bad numberpower to increase the number of permits which bad been fixed at two by the Regional Transport Authority under s. 47  3  to three on the application of an aggrieved person under s. 64-A arising from a proceeding before the Regional Transport Authority under a. 48 and the Appellate Authority under s. 61.
